review.title: Benders Decomposition for the Design of a Hub and Shuttle Public Transit System
review.abstract: The BusPlus project aims at improving the off-peak hours public transit service in Canberra, Australia. To address the difficulty of covering a large geographic area, BusPlus proposes a hub and shuttle model consisting of a combination of a few high-frequency bus routes between key hubs and a large number of shuttles that bring passengers from their origin to the closest hub and take them from their last bus stop to their destination. This paper focuses on the design of bus network and proposes an efficient solving method to this multimodal network design problem based on the Benders decomposition method. Starting from a MIP formulation of the problem, the paper presents a Benders decomposition approach using dedicated solution techniques for solving independent sub-problems, Pareto optimal cuts, cut bundling, and core point update. Computational results on real-world data from Canberra's public transit system justify the design choices and show that the approach outperforms the MIP formulation by two orders of magnitude. Moreover, the results show that the hub and shuttle model may decrease transit time by a factor of 2, while staying within the costs of the existing transit system.

sections.heading: 2. Modeling the HSPTS Problem for the BusPlus Project
sections.text: The HSPTS is a variant of the lift / arch location problem, where customers have access to a multimodal transport network, where buses run on a fixed network and taxis can transport customers on any pair of departure / destination points. Bus lines can be opened for a fixed price, which represents the cost of operating high frequency buses along the arc. The goal is to minimize the cost of the system, i.e. the fixed cost of operating the bus lines and the variable cost of each taxi ride, along with maximizing the convenience for the traveler. We use travel time as a substitute for the convenience of the traveler in the model. In order to make the design of the HSPTS controllable from a computational point of view, a number of simplifications are introduced. First, travel is modeled as a single commodity and the number of passengers is a factor in the cost of the journey. Second, the route and appointment aspects of the bus are ignored. Taxis are made available as in any place within a short time, and always from this system to the pick-up time.

sections.heading: 3. Review of Prior Work
sections.text: The problem of linking a number of hubs to arcs is called Hub-Arc Location Problem or Hub-Spoke Network Design Problem: It was introduced by Campbell et al. (2005a, b) and is defined as the problem of locating a certain number of hubs location problem in a way that minimizes total flow costs. It is mainly used in transshipment contexts where economies of scale can be expected through grouping flows. Hub-Arc Location Problem (HALP) can be considered a two-step decision problem, which arcs are opened first and then how the flow is conducted at minimal cost. As such, its structure appears ideally suited to benders decomposition (Benders 1962). In recent years, a significant research body has been devoted to solving variants of the hub location problem and the HALP using benders decomposition, which studies typically impose limitations on network topology.

Therefore, the original sub-problem for a given journey can be solved by calculation, whereby for each journey a shortest path between the origin and the destination using the edges defined by the union of Dr, the useful taxi sheets and Z, the amount of open bus legs in the current route. sections.text: This section presents experimental results on the HSTPS issue, starting with defining the primary environment, then justifying implementation decisions, including the benders scheme, the cut-bundling strategy and the core point-update rule. It also compares the final algorithm to a standard MIP approach. Finally, the section assesses the impact of the algorithm on the real case study that motivated this work: the restructuring of the Canberra public transport system.

sections.heading: 7.3. Benefits on the Case Study
sections.text: We conclude this section by evaluating the approach based on the real case study: The Canberra public transport system. Table 5 compares the results of our BusPlus approach with the current Canberra public transport system known as Action. For BusPlus, the table gives the cost of the bus network, the total cost of the system and the average travel time in the three columns. For Action, the table gives the cost of the system and the average travel time. Experimental settings differ slightly between BusPlus and Action to reflect the state of the system as accurately as possible. In particular, we do not take into account the waiting time when boarding the bus in action, as this data is not available. The main reason for this reduction is the significant number of journeys served by taxis. Furthermore, the results show that the BusPlus approach divides the average travel time by two, even taking into account the waiting time for the bus in action.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusion
sections.text: The BusPlus project aims to improve off-peak public transport in Canberra, Australia, covering a large geographical area that makes public transport particularly challenging. To address this difficulty, the BusPlus project proposes a lift and shuttle model consisting of a combination of some high-frequency bus lines between major hubs and a large number of shuttles that take passengers from their point of origin to the nearest hub and take them from their last bus stop to their destination. This paper focused on the design of the bus network, which can be modeled as a variant of the lift / arch problem. It proposed a series of pre-processing techniques, trip filtering and link filtering to reduce the problem size. It then introduced a bender decomposition approach that uses dedicated solution techniques to solve independent partial problems, Pareto optimal cuts, bundling and core point filtering to validate the benefits of these public design decisions.
